discourse_list.title: Ukraine Authorizes Cryptocurrency Exchanges and Banking

content.content: coindesk.com – 16 Mar 22    Ukraine's Zelenskyy Signs Virtual Assets Bill Into Law, Legalizing Crypto Ukraine has received $100 million in crypto donations during its war with Russia.
Russia inadvertently causing a base case for why Crypto is important
As a great crypto philosopher puts it. Bitcoin and crypto you don’t need it, until you need it.
Well, why privacy is important. Need more projects like Aztec and more use of such projects.

the Guardian – 1 Mar 22    Could Putin be exploring cryptocurrencies to bypass western sanctions? Debate rages over whether Russian banks could use crypto such as bitcoin as an alternative currency exchange

I initially wondered about that; not terribly concerned now.  Yes, as the article says Russia could through bitcoin mining convert oil into Bitcoin - very inefficiently though.  But after that I disagree that will let them purchase many tangible things.  Tangibles things require a shipper, and shippers are either outright refusing to service Russia or are too afraid Western European sanctions will change and their ships carrying goods to Russia will be seized.  So other than goods from China and assuming China will accept Bitcoin to pay for its goods (but I doubt China will so agree), I don’t think Russia can defeat the overall effectiveness of the sanctions with crypto.

It is curious because Venezuela has experience in circumventing sanctions, here the “government” has done everything to evade them, they use cryptocurrencies for payments, even with the issue of refining oil, they change Venezuelan flags for Iran on ships from even other countries. They even anchor ships in international waters so that the oil is later loaded onto another transport ship (in Venezuela a large part of food and other products are imported, curiously you can even get everything even Ferraris these days). For some reason the economic sanctions do not are effective in the capacity of exchanges between countries, there is always a way, a partner country? (maybe black markets). The only one affected by this situation will be the Russian people, who have little to do with the decisions of their “leader”.

That’s right @Alefcripto, unfortunately here in Venezuela we have experienced firsthand the futility of the sanctions imposed on the Maduro regime. As you say, there will always be alternative ways to evade sanctions, and in the end it is the common citizen who pays the consequences. History has shown us that sanctions can be an effective tool in the short term, but once time passes without achieving their objectives, they become useless. And what better example to cite than the case of Cuba.
